title: Big IPOs, Job Creation, Earnings Outlook
text:
Text size

Morning Briefing

by Yardeni Research

yardeni.com

Sept. 5: Initial public offerings have turned in a banner performance so far this year. The Renaissance IPO exchange-traded fund is up 30% through Tuesday’s close, down from its 44% year-to-date performance in July but still sharply outperforming the broader stock markets. Those returns are even more impressive given the sharp year-to-date declines in two of its holdings: Uber Technologies and Lyft.

The strong IPO returns are good news for the deals waiting in the wings, including SmileDirect Club, which sells clear aligners directly to consumers. They eliminate the need to go to an orthodontist and reduce the cost of straightening one’s teeth by 60%, SmileDirect says. The company, which is unprofitable, plans to raise up to $1.3 billion in its IPO.

SmileDirect and WeWork—which has a $3 billion IPO pending—both will use an umbrella partnership corporation, or an “up-C,” when they go public. “The structure allows companies to sell shares through a public holding company that owns a stake in an underlying limited liability company, where certain company executives and early investors continue to hold their economic interests. Unlike WeWork, SmileDirectClub also said it would use a so-called tax receivable agreement granting LLC members 85% of the savings generated by an increase in the company’s tax basis,” an Aug. 16 Financial Times article stated.

—Edward Yardeni

The Trade War Imperils Jobs

Hot Charts

by National Bank of Canada

nbc.ca

Sept. 5: Nearly 1.4 million private-sector jobs were created in the first eight months of 2019 in the U.S. according to the ADP...…Firms with 500 or more employees have created roughly a half-million private-sector jobs so far this year. In other words, those large firms account for 36% of private-sector job creation this year, the highest share since 2010. Such growing dependence on large firms arguably makes the U.S. labor market more vulnerable to the escalating U.S.-China trade war.…Unless there is a superpower truce, it’s hard to see U.S. job creation maintaining the pace in ’20.

—Krishen Rangasamy

S&P 500 Earnings Outlook

U.S. Investment Policy Committee Notes

by CFRA

cfraresearch.com

Sept. 4: Investors have a lot to worry about over the coming month, from general economic data and their impact on the Federal Reserve’s decision to lower rates at the midmonth Federal Open Market Committee meeting, to the ongoing trade dispute and the continued softening of third-quarter S&P 500 index earnings-per-share growth expectations. Indeed, S&P 500 third-quarter EPS is now projected to decline 3.3%, year on year, according to S&P Capital IQ consensus estimates, versus the 0.2% shortfall anticipated on June 30. What’s more, mid- and small-cap benchmarks had even deeper reductions to estimates, while 10 of 11 sectors saw downward revisions to their third-quarter growth forecasts, led by the consumer-discretionary, energy, and materials sectors. Only real estate saw improved expectations. But we don’t see an EPS recession, as fourth-quarter’ growth estimate of 3.8% should more than offset third-quarter’s weakness. Sam Stovall
